awd_titl_txt: The Role of Grafting Mechanism on the Self-Assembly and Properties of Polymer Nanocomposites
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY: 

The addition of inorganic nanoparticles  (NPs) to a polymer (i.e. a plastic material) can result in hybrid materials with highly improved properties. A classic example is that, while rubber (as e.g. in an eraser) has extremely poor wear resistance, the addition of silica nanoparticles causes the wear resistance to go up so much that a car can drive with tires that last over 50,000 miles.  While such property improvements are what drive developments in the field of polymer nanocomposites, the inherent problem is that the nanoparticles are chemically so different from the polymer (a hydrocarbon material) and thus have a strong tendency to separate from each other akin to a water-oil suspension. Thus, the desirable, favorable property improvements that can only be realized by the intimate mixing of the polymer and the NPs become hard to realize on a routine basis. The work here proposes to remedy this problem by chemically grafting polymer chains onto the NPs so that the inorganic particle surface can be "shielded" from the polymer, thus allowing miscibility to be obtained. In particular, the work focuses on two strategies for this grafting: either grafting fully formed chains to the surfaces, or growing the chains piece-by-piece from the surface. Which of these strategies allows better control over particle-polymer miscibility and therefore improve properties the most is the focus of this research.  In addition to this technical emphasis, the proposed work will also stress the broad, interdisciplinary education of students and the recruitment and retention of women and minority students into STEM programs by attracting high-school and undergraduate students into engineering research activities in the PI's laboratory.



TECHNICAL SUMMARY: 

The focus of this proposal is on the self-assembly of polymer-grafted nanoparticles (NPs) in a polymer matrix with the goal of impacting the behavior of the resulting hybrid (or composite) material. This physical situation has relevance to improved performance in, for example, rubber tires and epoxies (which are used in electronic packaging and computer chip applications). This underpinning question will be studied through the exploration of three test-beds by judiciously combining theory and experiments. In particular, emphasis will be placed on role of the mechanism by which chains are grafted onto NP surfaces on the final material properties, i.e., whether the chains are preformed and attached to the surface or if the chains are grown link-by-link from the surface. It is expected that the former mechanism will yield a more uniform polymer coverage on the NP surface. The consequence of these differences in surface coverage on the assemblies formed and the resulting properties is the ultimate focus of this work. These research activities are coupled to extensive education and outreach activities. A major focus will be to recruit underrepresented students (both women and minorities) at both the undergraduate and graduate levels.  It is planned to grow both the current summer high-school research program, and also the research-experiences-for-undergraduates program during the schoolyear, with the goal of recruiting (and hopefully retaining) women and minorities into STEM efforts.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE TRUSTEES OF COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY IN THE CITY OF NEW YORK

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Over the last 15 years the PI has received continuous funding from DMR to work on the fundamental physics of polymer nanocomposites. Here, he has focused on studying  assemblies of spherical nanoparticles and how they can tune the properties of crosslinked networks. This topic is germane topic isince it is relevant to tires (styrene-butadiene rubbers filled with NPs), and glues in semiconductor manufacturing (filled epoxies).The current work focused on understanding the role of the size and the shape of self-assembled NP clusters (intimately controlled by the grafting strategy and which typically play the role of network junctions) on mechanical reinforcement. In summary, it was found that there are almost two separate elements in mechanical reinforcement ? first is that NP assemblies reinforce the melt, as has been studied extensively by us 10 years ago. Second, is the coupling between the crosslinked polymer network and the NP assembly, which seems to be completely understood in the framework of Flory-Rehner theory. This study thus gives a clear understanding of the optimal NP dispersion state in reinforcing polymer networks.

The broader impacts of this funded research are multipronged. First, the PI has been invited to present multiple talks based on the outcomes of this (and related) research. In the 2022-23 academic year, the PI has presented/will present ~10 talks both in the US and abroad. The PI is a visiting Chevron Professor, IIT Madras (Dec. ?19-to date) and Distinguished visiting professor, IIT Mumbai (?22 ? to date). He also chaired the Polymer Physics Gordon Research Conference, Summer ?22.

In addition to these external recognitions, the most important contributions of our efforts are in the training of students and post-docs. Dan Zhao, who graduated with a PhD from the group in ?17, and Mayank Jhalaria PhD ?21 both joined the Dow Corporation. Deboleena Dhara finished her PhD in ?23. Several MS, undergraduate and high school students worked on this program. Beatrice Bellini visited from the University of Bologna to do research that will lead to her MS degree ? she has now come back to Columbia to do her PhD. Reha Mathur (junior at Princeton) worked in our group on understanding the effects of nanoparticles on elastomer networks. Thus, our educational activities have been broad and have gone all the way from recruiting students into STEM programs to retaining them in related activities.

The PIs group has mentored BS level research students year-round, while on average 5 undergraduate students spend their summers performing research in the group. An important element here is that 2-3 of these summer students are funded by the Amazon/SURE program which is focused on building a PhD pipeline for underrepresented students. In this vein the PI trained Isabella Huang (rising senior, NYU), and Bridgie Cawthorn (rising senior, Univ of Tennessee) in our labs as part of Amazon/SURE REU efforts in summer ?22. Similarly, the group had two more Amazon/SURE underrepresented students work in our lab in summer ?21. Kawamura (Case Western) was an REU student funded by the NSF REU site at Columbia, again during summer ?22. Additionally, over the last four semesters the PI had Natalia Cislo (senior, Barnard), Maya Schuhert (senior, Columbia) working in our labs assisting PhD students in their research activities. ~60% of all of the junior colleagues in the group are women, highlighting our efforts to create pipelines for underrepresented students into the PhD program and beyond. In addition to these undergraduate students, the group routinely has 5 MS students working in our labs. 

 

 


Last Modified: 09/28/2023
Modified by: Sanat K Kumar
